flowRoot.flowPara: For every malfunction, whether medical, mechanical, or electronic, there is a rich assortment of prospective treatments, each with someone claiming their treatment is best. What has been lacking is a taxonomy of treatments and an objective rating system, so that everyone can rationally compare disparate treatments, like when comparing prospective chiropractic, surgical, and drug treatments for the same condition.

Where effects or side effects are uncertain, their value should be multiplied by their guesstimated probabilities. For example, one-day post-surgical use of oxycodone in a hospital setting incurs little risk of addiction, restoring its 2.9 rating with this use limitation.

This classification system is far from perfect. For example, it tends to favor drugs that usually do good things, but sometimes kills those who take them. Every prospective treatment has its own “story”, which includes its cost, risk, availability, and suitability to a particular task.I welcome any and all suggested improvements to this classification system.

Within a category, some treatments work better than others and this is represented by a fractional part of the number. For example, for pain relief an aspirin might be rated 2.1, while oxycodone (trade name Oxycontin and often referred to as synthetic heroin) might be rated at 2.9, until its highly addictive side effects are considered.

Many treatments have expected side effects. The value of these side effects, measured by the value of an effective treatment for them, must be subtracted from the value of the beneficial effects according to the same scale. For example, while oxycodone is an excellent 2.9 pain reliever, it often produces lifelong addiction, the cure for which would be rated at 7, for a net loss of 4.1 or more, rounding to the nearest integer for negative results, rates oxycodone at a deplorable minus 4.
A placebo that does nothing other than psychological effects.
Preventative measures that address no present illness, like dietary supplements or changing the oil.
Temporarily affects a measurement, like blood or oil pressure, without significantly affecting symptoms.
Temporarily affects symptoms, like pain or smoke, without affecting the illness.
Temporarily affects the results of the illness, like inflammation or computer crashes, without affecting the underlying illness.
Temporarily affects essential problems from an illness, like airway obstruction or engine operation, without affecting the illness.

Temporarily affects or eliminates an illness, like supplementing an essential nutrient that has been missing from the diet, or adding oil to a car that burns oil, without any expectation that the illness is permanently eliminated. Chiropractic treatments typically fall into this category.

Eliminates an illness, like changing a flat tire or surgically removing a tumor, without any expectation that the same or similar illnesses won’t recur in the future. Surgical interventions typically fall into this category, until their side effects are considered.

Corrects a systemic issue, like replacing a defective thermostat or correcting an errant body temperature, which may eliminate several illnesses including the one being treated, and assure they won’t recur so long as the issue remains resolved, but without any assurance that the systemic issue won’t recur in the future.

Corrects something, and includes any necessary one-time measures to assure that the condition will never recur in the future. This is sometimes accomplished through the use of continuous monitoring systems, or training users to recognize the first signs of impending problems. This is a true cure.
